rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 181: Line 181:
In 1989 [[Time Inc.]] acquired Warner Communications and merged the two enterprises to create [[Time Warner]] in a deal valued at US$14 billion<ref>[http://ketupa.net/time2.htm ketupa.net - Time Warner: Warner Bros and Warner Communications]</ref>. Through the 1990s it was the largest media company in the world, with assets in excess of US$20 billion and annual revenues in the billions of dollars; by 1991, Warner's music labels were generating sales valued at more than US$3 billion, with operating profits of $550 million<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/21/obituaries/the-creator-of-time-warner-steven-j-ross-is-dead-at-65.html?sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all Roger Cohen, "The Creator of Time Warner, Steven J. Ross, Is Dead at 65", ''New York Times'', 21 December 1992. (Accessed 22 Feb. 2010)]</ref>. Acquisitions and corporate changes within the Warner group of labels fold continued after the Time Warner merger -- in 1990 WEA purchased French label [[Carrere Disques]], WEA was renamed [[Warner Music]] in 1991, leading French classical label [[Erato]] (1992) and in 1993 WEA bought the Spanish [[DRO Group]], Hungary's [[Magneoton]] label, the Swedish [[Telegram Records]], Brazil's [[Continental Records]] and Finnish label [[Fazer Musiiki]]. In 1994, [[Seagram]] acquired a stake in Time Warner.
In 1989 [[Time Inc.]] acquired Warner Communications and merged the two enterprises to create [[Time Warner]] in a deal valued at US$14 billion<ref>[http://ketupa.net/time2.htm ketupa.net - Time Warner: Warner Bros and Warner Communications]</ref>. Through the 1990s it was the largest media company in the world, with assets in excess of US$20 billion and annual revenues in the billions of dollars; by 1991, Warner's music labels were generating sales valued at more than US$3 billion, with operating profits of $550 million<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/21/obituaries/the-creator-of-time-warner-steven-j-ross-is-dead-at-65.html?sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all Roger Cohen, "The Creator of Time Warner, Steven J. Ross, Is Dead at 65", ''New York Times'', 21 December 1992. (Accessed 22 Feb. 2010)]</ref>. Acquisitions and corporate changes within the Warner group of labels fold continued after the Time Warner merger -- in 1990 WEA purchased French label [[Carrere Disques]], WEA was renamed [[Warner Music]] in 1991, leading French classical label [[Erato]] (1992) and in 1993 WEA bought the Spanish [[DRO Group]], Hungary's [[Magneoton]] label, the Swedish [[Telegram Records]], Brazil's [[Continental Records]] and Finnish label [[Fazer Musiiki]]. In 1994, [[Seagram]] acquired a stake in Time Warner.
â
On the recording front, Warner artists continued to do major business. Prince enjoyed a number of substantial hits in this period but his relationship with the company grew increasingly strained in the mid-90s, climaxing in a highly publicized battle over the ownership of his master recordings, Warner Bros attitude to his recordings and his desire to be released from his contract. During 1990 Prince made his fourth film, ''[[Graffiti Bridge]]'', accompanied by an album of the same name. Warner Bros Pictures was initially reluctant to produce the film, but thanks to assurances that it would be a sequel to the hugely successful ''Purple Rain'', with the involvement of [[The Time]], [[Mavis Staples]] and [[George Clinton]], the studio approved the project. The film was panned by critics and bombed at the box office, grossing just $4.2 million<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099691/business IMDb - ''Graffiti Bridge'' - Box office]</ref> but the recordings fared considerably better -- the album reached #6 on the Billboard 200 and R&B albums chart, and the single "Thieves in the Temple" reached #6 on the Hot 100 and #1 on the R&B chart. The next single "Round and Round", which featured featured the teenage [[Tevin Campbell]] on lead vocals, reached #12 on the Hot 100 and #2 on the R&B charts. Prince rebounded in 1991 with his thirteenth album ''[[Diamonds and Pearls]]'', which reached #3 on the Billboard 200, #2 in the UK and #1 in Australia. Five of the six singles lifted from the album charted in the US and other countries; "Gett Off" reached #21 on the Hot 100 and #6 on the R&B charts while "Cream" gave Prince his fifth US #1 hit and also reached #2 in Australia; "Insatiable" was a US #3 R&B hit and "Money Don't Matter 2 Night" was a hit in several countries, reaching #23 (Hot 200) and #14 (R&B) in the USA, #19 in the UK, and #18 in Australia. His 1992 album, [[File:Prince logo.svg|12px]] was identified by a cryptic symbol on the cover (later defined as "The Love Symbol"). It was successful, peaking at #5 on the ''Billboard'' 200<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/discography/more.jsp?tp=albums&pid=5451&aid=49118 |title=Discography (more) - Prince & The New Power Generation â The Love Symbol Album |publisher=Billboard.com |date=1992-10-31 |accessdate=2009-07-18}}</ref> and selling 2.8 million copies worldwide<ref>{{cite news|title=Possessed: The Rise And Fall Of Prince|author= Alex Hahn| publisher=Billboard Books|year=2003}} Retrieved on May 15, 2007 pg. 187</ref>. Although Warners wanted "[[7 (song)|7]]" as the first single, Prince successfully pushed for "[[My Name Is Prince]]" as the lead single, but it only reached #36 on the Hot 100 and #23 on the R&B chart. The follow-up single "[[Sexy MF]]" fared poorly, only reaching #66 on the Hot 100 and #76 on the R&B chart. In the event, "7" became the only Top 10 single from the album, peaking (appropriately) at #7 in the US.
+
On the recording front, Warner artists continued to do major business. Prince enjoyed a number of substantial hits in this period but his relationship with the company grew increasingly strained in the mid-90s, climaxing in a highly publicized battle over the ownership of his master recordings, Warner Bros attitude to his recordings and his desire to be released from his contract. During 1990 Prince made his fourth film, ''[[Graffiti Bridge]]'', accompanied by an album of the same name. Warner Bros Pictures was initially reluctant to produce the film, but thanks to assurances that it would be a sequel to the hugely successful ''Purple Rain'', with the involvement of [[The Time]], [[Mavis Staples]] and [[George Clinton]], the studio approved the project. The film was panned by critics and bombed at the box office, grossing just $4.2 million<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099691/business IMDb - ''Graffiti Bridge'' - Box office]</ref> but the recordings fared considerably better -- the album reached #6 on the Billboard 200 and R&B albums chart, and the single "Thieves in the Temple" reached #6 on the Hot 100 and #1 on the R&B chart. The next single "Round and Round", which featured featured the teenage [[Tevin Campbell]] on lead vocals, reached #12 on the Hot 100 and #2 on the R&B charts. Prince rebounded in 1991 with his thirteenth album ''[[Diamonds and Pearls]]'', which reached #3 on the Billboard 200, #2 in the UK and #1 in Australia. Five of the six singles lifted from the album charted in the US and other countries; "Gett Off" reached #21 on the Hot 100 and #6 on the R&B charts while "Cream" gave Prince his fifth US #1 hit and also reached #2 in Australia; "Insatiable" was a US #3 R&B hit and "Money Don't Matter 2 Night" was a hit in several countries, reaching #23 (Hot 200) and #14 (R&B) in the USA, #19 in the UK, and #18 in Australia. His 1992 album, [[Love Symbol Album]] was identified by a cryptic symbol on the cover (later defined as "The Love Symbol"). It was successful, peaking at #5 on the ''Billboard'' 200<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/discography/more.jsp?tp=albums&pid=5451&aid=49118 |title=Discography (more) - Prince & The New Power Generation â The Love Symbol Album |publisher=Billboard.com |date=1992-10-31 |accessdate=2009-07-18}}</ref> and selling 2.8 million copies worldwide<ref>{{cite news|title=Possessed: The Rise And Fall Of Prince|author= Alex Hahn| publisher=Billboard Books|year=2003}} Retrieved on May 15, 2007 pg. 187</ref>. Although Warners wanted "[[7 (song)|7]]" as the first single, Prince successfully pushed for "[[My Name Is Prince]]" as the lead single, but it only reached #36 on the Hot 100 and #23 on the R&B chart. The follow-up single "[[Sexy MF]]" fared poorly, only reaching #66 on the Hot 100 and #76 on the R&B chart. In the event, "7" became the only Top 10 single from the album, peaking (appropriately) at #7 in the US.
In 1993 Warner Bros released the three-disc "[[Greatest Hits]]" compilation ''[[The Hits/The B-Sides]]''; the same year Prince stopped using his first name and adopted the so-called "Love Symbol", but because this was unpronounceable, he was generally referred to as "The Artist Formerly Known as Prince". By 1994, relations between Prince and Warners had broken down and he launched legal action to extricate himself from his contract. Prince claimed that Warner Bros was limiting his artistic freedom by insisting that he release albums less frequently, blaming them for the poor commercial performance of the 'Love Symbol' album, and to highlight his view he began appearing in public with the word "SLAVE" written on his cheek. It was during this period that Warner Bros issued the shelved ''Black Album'', even though it was already in wide circulation as a bootleg; it was released as a limited edition, but sold relatively poorly and was soon deleted. Warner Bros then acceded to Prince's wishes to issue his new album ''[[Come (album)|Come]]'' but it appeared to confirm the label's fears, becoming his poorest-selling album to date, shift barely 500,000 copies. Prince pushed to have his next album ''[[The Gold Experience]]'' released simultaneously with the Love Symbol-era material but Warners' reluctance to release it sparked Prince's lawsuit. Warner Bros. allowed the single "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World" (Feb. 1994) to be released via a small, independent distributor, in February 1994 and it reached #1 in the U.S. and several other countries, but Warners still resisted releasing ''The Gold Experience'', fearing poor sales and citing "market saturation" as a defense. When eventually issued in September 1995, the album indeed failed to sell well, although it briefly entered the top 10 of the Billboard 200 and many reviewers praised it as Prince's best effort since ''Sign o' the Times''. ''[[Chaos and Disorder]]'' (1996) was his final album of new material for Warner Bros, and not surprisingly it proved to be one of his least successful releases. He subsequently released recordings on his own NPG label (via [[EMI]]) before eventually signing with [[Universal Music]] in 2005.
In 1993 Warner Bros released the three-disc "[[Greatest Hits]]" compilation ''[[The Hits/The B-Sides]]''; the same year Prince stopped using his first name and adopted the so-called "Love Symbol", but because this was unpronounceable, he was generally referred to as "The Artist Formerly Known as Prince". By 1994, relations between Prince and Warners had broken down and he launched legal action to extricate himself from his contract. Prince claimed that Warner Bros was limiting his artistic freedom by insisting that he release albums less frequently, blaming them for the poor commercial performance of the 'Love Symbol' album, and to highlight his view he began appearing in public with the word "SLAVE" written on his cheek. It was during this period that Warner Bros issued the shelved ''Black Album'', even though it was already in wide circulation as a bootleg; it was released as a limited edition, but sold relatively poorly and was soon deleted. Warner Bros then acceded to Prince's wishes to issue his new album ''[[Come (album)|Come]]'' but it appeared to confirm the label's fears, becoming his poorest-selling album to date, shift barely 500,000 copies. Prince pushed to have his next album ''[[The Gold Experience]]'' released simultaneously with the Love Symbol-era material but Warners' reluctance to release it sparked Prince's lawsuit. Warner Bros. allowed the single "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World" (Feb. 1994) to be released via a small, independent distributor, in February 1994 and it reached #1 in the U.S. and several other countries, but Warners still resisted releasing ''The Gold Experience'', fearing poor sales and citing "market saturation" as a defense. When eventually issued in September 1995, the album indeed failed to sell well, although it briefly entered the top 10 of the Billboard 200 and many reviewers praised it as Prince's best effort since ''Sign o' the Times''. ''[[Chaos and Disorder]]'' (1996) was his final album of new material for Warner Bros, and not surprisingly it proved to be one of his least successful releases. He subsequently released recordings on his own NPG label (via [[EMI]]) before eventually signing with [[Universal Music]] in 2005.
